title: Height Estimation
question_text:
Suppose the heights of American men are normally distributed with a mean of $68\text{ inches}$ and a standard deviation of $2.5\text{ inches}$. Ted’s height is at the $20^\text{th}$ percentile.
To the nearest inch, how tall is Ted?
solution:

The $20^\text{th}$ percentile means that $20\%$ of the curve will be to the left of Ted’s height, and $80\%$ will be to the right.

Use the table of standard normal probabilities or the “inverse normal” function on a calculator corresponding to an area (not a $z$-value) of $0.2000$, and the corresponding $z$-value will be $-0.84$.

Now use the conversion formula:

$$z =\dfrac{ (X - \mu )}{ \sigma }$$

$$-0.84 = \dfrac{(X-68)}{2.5}$$

Solving for Ted’s height $X$ yields the following:

$$(-0.84)(2.5) = X-68$$

$$-2.1 = X-68$$

$$X = 66.1$$

So then $66.1$ rounds to $66$. Choice 'D' is correct.
